revisions.rev:
{{Infobox writer |name = Josh Schwartz |image = Josh Schwartz Infobox photo.jpg |imagesize = 180px |caption = Josh Schwartz, 2007 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|8|6}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]], [[Rhode Island]], [[United States|U.S.]]}} |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = [[Television producer|Producer]]
[[Screenwriter]] |spouse = Jill Stonerock
(m. 2008âpresent) |nationality = [[United States|American]] |notableworks = ''[[The O.C.]]''
''[[Gossip Girl]]''
''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' |influences = [[Cameron Crowe]], [[Woody Allen]]{{cite video | people = [[Charlie Rose]] (interviewer) | date = November 22, 2004 | title = The Charlie Rose Show: A Conversation with Josh Schwartz | url = http://www.charlierose.com/shows/2004/11/22/2/a-conversation-with-the-o-c-creator-josh-schwartz | format = Flash | medium = Television production | accessdate = 2007-08-15}} |influenced = |website = }} '''Josh Schwartz''' (born August 6, 1976) is an [[United States|American]] [[screenwriter]] and [[television producer]]. Schwartz is best known for creating and executive producing the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] drama ''[[The O.C.]]'' Schwartz recently developed [[The CW Television Network|The CW]]'s teen drama series, ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' from the ''[[Gossip Girl (novel series)|Gossip Girl]]'' books series, and co-created [[NBC]]'s action-comedy-spy series, ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]''. At 26, he became the youngest person in network history to create a network series and run its day-to-day production when he ran ''[[The O.C.]]'' He currently resides in [[Los Angeles]].{{cite web |title=Endeavor trio partner up: Agency ups Donnelly, Hodes, Wiczyk |author=Michael Fleming |date=2005-11-03 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117932314.html?categoryid=29&cs=1 |publisher=Variety |accessdate=2007-01-06}} ==Early life== Schwartz was born in 1976 in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] to Steve and Honey Schwartz. His parents were both toy inventors at [[Hasbro]], working on the development of toys such as [[Transformers (toy line)|Transformers]] and [[My Little Pony]], until they went on to start their own company.{{cite news |title=The man behind the OC |author=Hadley Freeman |date=2005-01-22 |publisher=Guardian Unlimited |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/weekend/story/0,,1394603,00.html |accessdate=2007-01-16 | location=London}}{{cite news|title="On the Scene": "The O.C." |author=Michael Elkin |work=The Jewish Exponent |location=Philadelphia |url=http://www.interfaithfamily.com/site/apps/nl/content2.asp?c=ekLSK5MLIrG&b=297399&ct=412979 |accessdate=2007-01-07}} Schwartz grew up on the East side of Providence, Rhode Island with a younger brother, Danny, and a younger sister, Katie.{{cite news |title=People: O.C. creator to speak at Wheeler, his alma mater |author=Andy Smith |date=2005-06-10 |work=The Providence Journal |url=http://www.projo.com/extra/graduation/highschool/content/projo_20050610_schwartz.1bd26e5.html |accessdate=2007-01-08}}{{cite news|last =Engelberg| first =Keren| title =Young Creator Spells Success âO.C.â |work=The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles| date=2003-10-31 | url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/home/preview.php?id=11286 |accessdate=2007-01-16 }} Schwartz always had ambitions of being a writer since early childhood.{{cite news |title=Charmed life: Young writerâs made it big with Fox hit |author=Curt Schleier |date=2004-03-19 |work=The Jewish News Weekly of Northern California |url=http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/21864/edition_id/443/format/html/displaystory.html |accessdate=2007-01-16}} When Schwartz was seven years old, he won an essay-writing contest at [[Summer camp|sleep-away camp]] for a review of the recently released movie ''[[Gremlins]]''; the opening line was "Spielberg has done it again" and stood out amongst the pile of essays from the other kids.{{cite news |title='The O.C.' Rewrites the Rules of TV Writing |author=Ari Posner |date=2004-03-21 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/21/arts/television/21POSN.html?ex=1395205200&en=158d7ee8845cb98e&ei=5007&partner=USERLAND |accessdate=2007-01-08 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} He even had a subscription to the entertainment industry newspaper ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' at age twelve.{{cite news |title=Questions for Josh Schwartz: Gossip Guy |author=Deborah Solomon |date=2007-10-14 |work=The New York Times |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/14/magazine/14wwln-q4-t.html |accessdate=2007-10-20}} He attended Providence's private [[Wheeler School]], a coeducational independent day school, for 11 years, graduating with the class of 1994.{{cite news |title=For Producer of Hit Show "The O.C.," Jewish Background Is Fertile Ground |author=Richard Asinof |date=2005-06-15 |publisher=JTA.Org |url=http://www.interfaithfamily.com/site/apps/nl/content2.asp?c=ekLSK5MLIrG&b=297403&ct=1368283 |accessdate=2007-01-07}} {{cquote|I was in fourth grade, back in 1986 or '87, and I was at my first concert: [[Huey Lewis and the News]] at the [[DCU Center|Worcester Centrum]]. It's not the coolest story in the world. I was standing on my seat, on the tip of my feet, and Huey made like he had fake binoculars to scope out the audience. Then he pointed at me and said, 'This song is dedicated to that little guy right there.' It was [[The Power of Love (Huey Lewis and the News song)|"The Power of Love"]]. That kicked it all off for me right there.|||Josh Schwartz, on music. }} ==Film school at USC== In 1995, Schwartz realized his boyhood dream of attending [[film school]] to study screen and television writing at the [[University of Southern California]]. He became a member of the [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] fraternity, as well as president of the chapter, and got to see what it's like "behind the [[Gated community|gated communities]] and big [[mansion]]s" of Southern California which would later provide fodder for his pilot ''The O.C.''{{cite web |title=Schwartz struts his stuff on 'O.C.' |author=Kim Holmes |date=2004-04-22 |publisher=Daily Trojan |url=http://www.dailytrojan.com/media/storage/paper679/news/2004/04/22/Lifestyle/Schwartz.Struts.His.Stuff.On.o.c-667916.shtml?norewrite200701071734&sourcedomain=www.dailytrojan.com |accessdate=2007-01-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|title=Exclusive Interview: Josh Schwartz, Creator/Executive Producer of The OC| url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/the-oc/exclusive-interview-josh-scwar-2651.aspx |publisher=BuddyTV |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2007-01-04}} He was an outsider, and met many kids from Newport Beach.{{cite web |title=The OC revealed |author=Libby Slate |year=2005 |publisher=Academy of Television Arts and Sciences |url=http://www.emmys.org/events/2005/theoc.php |accessdate=2007-01-16}} While at USC, Schwartz tried out [[stand-up comedy]] at a talent show in front of five hundred people but was "disabused of [the] notion very quickly." In his [[Student#Years|sophomore year]] he wrote an autobiographical screenplay about his senior year in high school called ''Providence'' as a homework assignment for school. He entered his screenplay into a contest for the prestigious Nicholson Award in Screenwriting, the highest honor awarded to undergraduates, and won. Unfortunately, the prize was quickly revoked; to be eligible he had to be in his junior year at the time. Schwartz says "I dropped it in a box â I was a sophomore. And I got a call over the summer saying I'd won, and I'd won five thousand dollars. I was like, "This is awesome!" Then they called back, like, the next day and said you had to be a junior to enter and not a sophomore, so they were rescinding it. I was pretty pissed."{{cite web|title=Schwartz uses youth to his advantageâ¦A look behind The O.C.| author=Molly Shalgos |year=2004|month=May |publisher=Lumino Magazine |url=http://www.luminomagazine.com/2004.05/spotlight/ocpf.html |accessdate=2007-01-04}} Nevertheless, with help from connections through his fraternity, he generated interest in Hollywood to buy his screenplay. In 1997, Sony's [[TriStar Pictures]] bought his first screenplay in a bidding war for a deal guaranteeing $550,000 and worth up to $1 million while he was still a [[Student#Years|junior]] in college. It was never made.{{cite web|title=Big Journey at WB; Foster exits 'Double' |author=Michael Fleming |date=1997-12-15 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR111776851.html?categoryid=3&cs=1 |accessdate=2007-01-07}} Schwartz got an agent and subsequently wrote a TV pilot called ''Brookfield'' for [[Disney-ABC Television Group|ABC/Disney]] while he was still studying at USC. It was a boarding school drama about wealthy kids in New England and was his first TV pilot script; it sold only a few months after he had sold his first feature film script. ''Brookfield'' was produced starring Amy Smart and Eric Balfour but never aired. Schwartz then dropped out of USC to work full-time{{cite web |title=Young Hollywood guns flex primetime muscle |author=Cynthia Littleton |date=2003-08-04 |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1947702 |accessdate=2007-01-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and wrote another pilot called ''Wall to Wall Records'', a drama about working in a music store for [[Warner Bros. Television|Warner Bros. TV]] that was also produced but never aired.{{cite web|title=The O.C. |url=http://fox61tv.com/first/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=129&Itemid=48 |publisher=Fox61tv.com |accessdate=2007-01-04}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==''The O.C.''== {{main|The O.C.}} In 2003, Schwartz wrote a pilot called ''[[The O.C.]]'' for [[Warner Bros. Television|Warner Bros. TV]] and [[Wonderland Sound and Vision]] which was produced with him as creator and executive producer. At 26 he was the youngest ever creator of a TV show, which did not sit well with Fox executives who sent a series of seasoned pros armed with conventional ideas about how to steer the show and a bitterness about sharing control with someone so young. That changed when Bob DeLaurentis signed on, a TV veteran who proved to be a nurturing presence on the show. Schwartz and Bob DeLaurentis collaborated on supervising and approving the editors' work on each episode in [[post-production]].[http://www.theocshow.com/news/news_82.htm The OC Show - OC News Articles] ''The O.C.'' became an instant teen favorite when it debuted on the [[Fox Network]] in August 2003. The show popularized its setting, Orange County, and led to copycats like [[MTV]]'s reality show ''[[Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County]]'' and the [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]] documentary series ''[[The Real Housewives of Orange County]]''.{{cite web|title=Once hot, 'O.C.' now struggles |author=Suzanne C. Ryan |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2006/10/29/occupational_hazard/ |date=2006-10-29 |publisher=The Boston Globe |accessdate=2007-01-04}} The show became well known for [[The O.C.#Music from the show|its music]], chosen by Schwartz according to his own musical tastes and designed to reflect who the characters were, bringing an awareness to [[indie rock]] bands like [[Death Cab for Cutie]], [[Bloc Party]] and [[Rooney (band)|Rooney]].{{cite web |title=The DJ of 'The O.C.': Show creator's musical taste guides skein |author=Josef Adalian |date=2005-02-10 |work=Variety |accessdate=2007-01-07 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117917745.html?categoryid=1885&cs=1}} He has said that he partially based ''The O.C.'' character [[Seth Cohen]] on his own Jewish upbringing.{{cite web| title=Schwartz still likes hanging in âThe O.C.â |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12070285/ |publisher=MSNBC.com |date=2006-03-29 |accessdate=2007-01-04}} Schwartz was nominated for a [[Writers Guild of America]] Award for the pilot{{cite web |title=56th Annual Writers Guild Awards -- Television and Radio Nominees Announced |year=2004 |url=http://www.wgaeast.org/awards/2004/01/20/tvnom/ |accessdate=2007-01-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} as well as a [[People's Choice Award]]. ''The O.C.'' was named "Guilty Pleasure of the Year" by [[VH1]]. In 2007, after 4 seasons ''The O.C.'' was canceled due to a significant ratings drop.{{cite web|title=Fox bids farewell to 'The OC' |author=Michael Schneider |date=2007-01-03 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117956637.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |accessdate=2007-01-04}} Schwartz has stayed in touch with his alma maters: The Wheeler School and USC. In 2005, he endowed USC with its first television writing scholarship: The Josh Schwartz Scholarship. The scholarship is intended to be awarded annually to a student or students concentrating on writing for television and in need of financial assistance, who have completed a TV pilot script and first season synopsis.{{cite web |title=The OC" Creator Josh Schwartz Endows Inaugural Scholarship for Television Writing Students at USC School of Cinema-Television |url=http://cinema.usc.edu/summer/resources/newsDetail.cfm?news_id=197 |publisher=USC School of Cinematic Arts|accessdate=2007-01-04 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061204015341/http://cinema.usc.edu/summer/resources/newsDetail.cfm?news_id=197 |archivedate = 2006-12-04}} Although Schwartz never graduated from USC he has since worked with many USC alumni. In 2005 he gave a commencement speech to The Wheeler School. Schwartz has worked on his share of stalled projects. In 2004, he worked as a [[script doctor]] on the [[J. J. Abrams]] ''Superman'' screenplay that Warner Bros. eventually tossed.{{cite web |title=Supe's on with 'X' man: Singer flies with pic |author=Cathy Dunkley, Michael Fleming |date=2004-07-18 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117907948.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 |accessdate=2007-01-08}}{{cite web |title='Superman' back in orbit: Moritz, Adler in negotiations to produce |author=Michael Fleming, Cathy Dunkley |date=2004-06-16 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117906596.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |accessdate=2007-01-08}} He sold a pilot to Fox called ''Alphabet City'', a drama about a New York tabloid but it was never produced.Horn, John (March 21, 2004). "He's 'O.C.'s' fresh breeze: Infusing it with sly wit and detail, creator Josh Schwartz has raised the Fox drama above its prime-time soap trappings". ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' through ''[http://www.lexisnexis.com/universe LexisNexis Academic]''. Retrieved on August 15, 2007. He also worked on a drama for Fox called ''Athens'' described as an "OC" companion but it was never produced. According to the futon critic, ''Athens'' will explore the intertwined lives and loves of the fictional New England community of Athens, home to a prestigious university that acts as a dividing line between the rich outsiders who study and teach there, and the local townies who serve that population. Viewers will enter this world through the friendship of Jed Hall, a young English professor, and Ethan Frost, an 18-year-old freshman whose arrival changes the dynamics for everyone in Athens. Like Ryan and Seth on "The O.C.," Jed and Ethan will become unlikely partners in an alliance that will forever change them and the people of this town.{{cite web |title=Fox turning a triple play: Hit trio fields new timeslots |author=Josef Adalian, Michael Schneider |date=2004-05-18 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117905236.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |accessdate=2007-01-08}}{{cite web |title=Josh Schwartz of The O.C. Interview |author=Daniel Robert Epstein |publisher=UnderGroundOnline |url=http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmtv/features/theoc/default.asp |accessdate=2007-01-08}} ==Recent film and television projects== [[Image:Josh_Schwartz_at_Comic-Con.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Josh Schwartz at [[Comic-Con]] in July 2007]] {{See Also|Fake Empire Productions}} In 2005, Paramount signed Schwartz to adapt and direct [[John Green (author)|John Green]]'s young adult novel ''[[Looking for Alaska]]'' with producer Mark Waters.{{cite web|title= Par, Schwartz bake 'Alaska':'OC' creator 'Looking' for Paramount project |author=Dave McNary |date=2005-07-18 |publisher=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117926060.html?cs=1&s=h&p=0 |accessdate=2007-01-04}} It was revealed in late August 2006 that Schwartz would develop and executive produce a drama pilot for [[The CW Television Network]], based on the popular book series ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' by [[Cecily von Ziegesar]].{{cite web |title=CW gives Schwartz some good news: 2nd pilot picked up for show creator| author=Michael Schneider |coauthors=Josef Adalian |date=2007-01-03 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117956643.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |publisher=Variety |accessdate=2007-01-04}} Like ''The O.C.'', ''Gossip Girl'' is a satirical approach of teenagers in a wealthy upbringing. ''Gossip Girl'' has become a very popular show for The CW. In 2007, Schwartz signed a three-year, seven-figure overall deal with [[Warner Bros. Television|Warner Bros. TV]] to write and exec produce with Chris Fedak an hourlong [[high-concept]] action comedy called ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' for NBC about twenty-something spies and was described in press releases as "in the vein of ''[[Grosse Pointe Blank]]''". The plot revolves around a normal guy who downloads the entire CIA and NSA databases into his head.{{cite web|title= Networks return to pilot parade: ABC aligned with Mimoun; NBC nabs Schwartz project |author= Josef Adalian |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117950140.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |publisher=Variety|date=2006-09-14|accessdate=2007-01-04}} In May 2008, Schwartz joined [[Zak Penn]]'s ''[[X-Men: First Class]]'' project.{{cite news | title = Young X-Men Get Gossip Girl Scribe? | work = [[Superhero Hype!]] | date = 2008-05-02 | url = http://www.superherohype.com/news/topnews.php?id=7159 | accessdate=2008-05-03}} Schwartz announced that he will write the script for ''X-Men: First Class'', a prequel to the ''[[X-Men (film series)|X-Men]]'' movies that focuses on the adventures of teen [[Cyclops (comics)|Cyclops]], [[Jean Grey|Marvel Girl]], [[Professor X]], [[Beast (comics)|Beast]], [[Iceman (comics)|Iceman]], and [[Warren Worthington III|Angel]].{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117996099.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1|publisher= Variety|author=MARC GRASER, TATIANA SIEGEL|date= November 18, 2008|title= Fox, Josh Schwartz mutate 'X-Men'}} However, his script was later jettisoned.{{cite news | author = Kit, Borys | url = http://www.heatvisionblog.com/2009/12/bryan-singer-xmen-first-class-jack-the-giant-killer-q-and-a.html | title = Heat Vision Q&A: Bryan Singer on 'X-Men: First Class,' 'Avatar' and more | work = Heat Vision | date = 2009-12-21 | accessdate = 2010-04-26}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In Spring 2009, Schwartz launched "Rockville CA", a web-series on TheWB.com that follows young 20-somethings at a fictional rock club in Los Angeles.[http://www.dailycomet.com/article/20090403/BIGFUN/903319881/0/ARTICLES?Title=Music-TV-in-flux-in-Josh-Schwartz-s-Rockville-] There are twenty indie band performances in the episodes, including [[Lykke Li]], [[The Kooks]] and [[Kaiser Chiefs]].{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/15/arts/television/15karp.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=rockville%20josh%20schwartz&st=cse | work=The New York Times | title=Welcome to the Net, Mr. 'OC' | first=Ari | last=Karpel | date=2009-03-15 | accessdate=2010-05-07}} It was also announced that Schwartz would write and direct ''Bright Lights, Big City'' for MGM, based on the iconic debut [[Bright Lights, Big City (novel)|novel]] by [[Jay McInerney]]. Stephanie Savage was also announced as producer. Schwartz is now developing a pilot for The CW. The show is titled ''[[Hart of Dixie]]'' and is co-produced with longtime creative partner [[Stephanie Savage]] and stars former "O.C." castmember and personal friend of Schwartz, [[Rachel Bilson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/02/rachel-bilson-to-star-in-the-cws-dixie-pilot/|title=Rachel Bilson To Star In The CW's Dixie Pilot|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=February 8, 2011|accessdate=March 10, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2011/02/the-cw-announces-four-pilot-pickups-including-new-josh-schwartz-and-stephanie-savage-project.html|title=The CW orders four pilots, including new Josh Schwartz and Stephanie Savage project|last=Bricker|first=Tierney|date=February 1, 2011|accessdate=March 10, 2011}} At the same time, Schwartz is working on a ''Georgetown'' pilot for ABC.De Moraes, Lisa. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/02/AR2011020205923.html Can 'Georgetown' bring a bit of the 'O.C.' to D.C.?] ''[[Washington Post]]'', February 3, 2011. In September of 2011, it was announced by [[The CW Television Network|The CW]] that Schwartz and [[Stephanie Savage]] had been selected to develop the television adaption of [[Candace Bushnell]]'s ''[[The Carrie Diaries]]'', a prequel to the original ''[[Sex and the City]]'' television series.[http://www.deadline.com/2011/09/update-carries-diaries-now-officially-at-cw-with-gossip-girl-producers-on-board/ âThe Carrie Diariesâ Now Officially At CW With âGossip Girlâ Producers On Board], ''Deadline'', September 11, 2011 The series, set in the 1980s, will follow character [[Carrie Bradshaw]] during her years in high school. ==Personal life== On September 20, 2008, Schwartz married Jill Stonerock in [[Santa Barbara, California]]. Actress [[Rachel Bilson]], who portrayed Summer Roberts on Schwartz's show ''The O.C.'', was the maid of honor at the wedding. Currently the couple is expecting their first child due in 2012. He is [[Jewish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.observer.com/2008/style/gossip-girl-s-josh-schwartz-doesn-t-have-problem-racy-ads-or-jay-mcinerney|title=Gossip Girl's Josh Schwartz Doesn't Have a Problem With Racy Ads, or Jay McInerney|author=Irina Aleksander|date=2008-09-02|publisher=New York Observer|accessdate=2011-10-04}} ==Filmography== ===Crew=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 90%;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" align="center" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Film |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" align="center" ! Writer and executive producer || Web series |- |} ==See also== * ''[[Fake Empire Productions]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further information== * {{cite book |title=Created by: Inside the Minds of TV's Top Show Creators |last=Prigge |first=Steven |date=2005-09-30 |publisher=Silman-James Press |isbn=978-1879505827}} * {{cite video | people = [[Charlie Rose]] (interviewer) | date = November 22, 2004 | title = The Charlie Rose Show: A Conversation with Josh Schwartz | url = http://www.charlierose.com/shows/2004/11/22/2/a-conversation-with-the-o-c-creator-josh-schwartz | format = Flash | medium = Television production | accessdate = 2007-08-15}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * {{IMDb name|0777300|Josh Schwartz}} * [http://popgurls.com/article_show.php3?id=670 PopGurls Interview: Josh Schwartz] {{Persondata | NAME = Schwartz, Josh | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = August 6, 1976 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]], [[Rhode Island]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schwartz, Josh}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:American screenwriters]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:American Jews]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Providence, Rhode Island]] [[Category:University of Southern California alumni]] [[Category:American soap opera writers]] [[Category:The O.C.]] [[Category:Chuck (TV series)]] [[cs:Josh Schwartz]] [[de:Josh Schwartz]] [[es:Josh Schwartz]] [[fr:Josh Schwartz]] [[it:Josh Schwartz]] [[nl:Josh Schwartz]] [[pt:Josh Schwartz]] [[fi:Josh Schwartz]] [[sv:Josh Schwartz]]
